title: Income tax: Deduction up to R3 lakh available on royalty earned from book
text:
Other Articles Tax Talk: NPS a flexible & tax-friendly investment option for NRIs Insurance: In correct lane FPI holding in BSE 200 down marginally I bought a plot of land for Rs 50,000 in May 1979. I am planning to sell it for Rs 13 lakh. What will be the cost of acquisition?
— Pradeep Solanki
As per Section 55 of the Income-Tax Act, 1961 (the Act), where a capital asset became the property of the assessee before April 1, 1981, the assessee has the option to take the higher of fair market value of the asset as on April 1, 1981, or the actual cost of the asset as the cost of acquisition. Thus, you may take Rs 50,000, or the fair market value of the plot as on April 1, 1981, whichever is higher, as the cost of acquisition.
It may be noted that as per Section 55A of the I-T Act where the assessing officer is of opinion that value adopted by the assessee as on April 1, 1981, is higher than the fair market value as on that date, he can make reference to the valuation officer for determining the fair market value of the property.
What are the tax implications if I keep my flat unoccupied and stay in a rented house?
— Akhilesh Prasad
As per Section 23 of Income-Tax Act, if a person owns more than one house, then the annual value of one of the houses of his choice can be considered as nil and the annual value of the other house(s) shall be determined as prescribed for the purpose of computation of income from house property. However, in your case, as you own only one house, there shall be no tax implications in this regards, unless the said property is actually rented out.
I made a cash gift of Rs 7 lakh to my wife in 2013 and she bought jewellery with that money. The value of the jewellery as on March 2015 was Rs 9,10,000. What would be the implication of this while computing the net wealth of my wife for the assessment year 2015-16?
— Vinay Sharma
Section 4(1)(a)(i) of the Wealth Tax Act, 1957, provides that assets held by the spouse of an individual to whom such assets have been transferred directly or indirectly shall be included in computing the net wealth of the individual. Thus, in your case the value of jewellery held by your wife will be included in computation of your net wealth for assessment year 2015-16.
I am a freelance writer. In FY15, I earned Rs 5 lakh by writing articles. Am I entitled for a maximum deduction of Rs 3,00,000 under the I-T Act in respect of such income?
— Abhishek Kumar
Under Section 80QQB of the Income-Tax Act, a deduction of actual royalty earned, subject to maximum Rs 3,00,000 is available to the author of a book against such royalty/copyright fees subject to fulfillment of certain specified conditions. The term book, however, does not include brochures, commentaries, diaries, guides, journals, magazines, newspapers, pamphlets, school text-books, tracts and such similar publications. Hence, you are not entitled to avail the benefit of the said deduction. However, actual expenses incurred for earning such income are allowed under Chapter IV of the Act.
I received a residential flat as a gift from my father in February 2007. The flat was purchased by my father in March 1999 for Rs 10 lakh and now want to sell the flat. From which year would I get the indexation benefits for computing capital gain?
— Sundar Rao
While computing the capital gains arising on transfer of a capital asset acquired by the taxpayer under a gift or will, indexed cost of acquisition should be computed with reference to year in which the previous owner first held the asset and not the year in which taxpayer became the owner of asset.
In this respect, you may rely on the decision of Bombay High court in the case of CIT vs Manjula J Shah and the Delhi Tribunal in the case of Kamal Mishra vs ITO and can claim the indexation benefit considering the base year as financial year 1998-99.
